Context:
The Dental Office Administration program at the college offers students the opportunity to gain real-world experience in a dental practice setting during semester 2. Students are typically placed with a general or specialty dental practice for a minimum of 100 hours. After graduation, career opportunities include administrative dental assistant roles within dental practices, specialty group practices, and dental insurance companies. With experience, graduates may advance to become treatment coordinators, supervisors, or office managers. Dental Office Administration graduates are eligible to write the Ontario Dental Assistants Association (ODAA) Certified Dental Receptionist (CDR) examination.

Required courses for the program include Anatomy and Terminology I (ANAT 1032), The Clinical Environment I (CLIN 1001), Dental Office Theory I (DENT 1109), Dental Software I (DENT 1111), Transition to Work (DENT 1120), The Dynamic Dental Practice (DENT 1121), Anatomy and Terminology II (ANAT 1059), The Clinical Environment II (CLIN 1002), Dental Office Theory II (DENT 1122), Dental Software II (DENT 1123), and Field Education (DENT 1125). Students may also be required to take Introduction to College Communication (COMM 1000) based on placement test results. The graduate is expected to be able to reliably demonstrate the ability to become an integral part of a dental healthcare team upon completion of the program.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Dental Office Administration Program S115 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Program Learning Outcomes:
- Develop self-awareness and collaborative skills for positive working relationships and inclusive team environments.
- Relate models and theories of psychology and sociology to human behaviours in human services professions.
- Identify systemic barriers to equity and inclusion in Canadian society and their impact on marginalized groups.
- Recognize professional requirements and opportunities in various human services fields.
- Develop academic strengths and strategies for lifelong learning and career development.
- Apply communication and research skills to gather and convey information objectively.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition (Fall 2023): $3,906.00
- International Tuition (Fall 2024): $17,950.00
- Additional Costs (estimated for Fall 2023 and Fall 2024): tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees, subject to change

Financial Assistance:
- OSAP funding is available, given eligibility criteria are met.

Admission Requirements:
- Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent
- Grade 12 English (C or U)
- Attend an information session (recommended)
- Basic knowledge of keyboarding skills and computer skills (recommended)
- Mature students may apply with no OSSD.

**Note:** The information is subject to change without notice. Students are responsible for verifying the fee requirements at George Brown College.

Context: Nadia Boduryan is a George Brown College alumnus who graduated with an Ontario College Certificate in Dental Office Administration (S113 for Level I and S134 for Level II). Her studies covered the fundamentals of administrative dentistry, preparing her for employment. She has since found a career as a Head Patient Coordinator. George Brown College offers campus tours, information sessions, and tailored resources to help applicants with their applications. The college communicates via email.
